item.description:
This game is the Tennessee Edition of the American Trivia Challenge line of games. The questions are divided into multiple categories, including:
1. Business
2. People, Places, and Things
3. Arts & Sciences
4. Government & History
5. Fun & Games
6. Etcetera
7. Home State

The players must move around the board, correctly answering questions at each category stop along the way.
The game includes: 1 playing board, 1 numeral die, 1 compass die, 6 game pieces, 6 flag holders, 4800 trivia questions, and 800 home state questions.

Kampfgruppe Zwei is the second volume of a series of books which attempt to present a system for accurately representing combat during the Second World War from the perspective of small units and individuals. This title places it's emphasis on the wide variety of ground vehicles which were involved in the conflict. Whilst it is perfectly capable of being played as a 'stand alone' system in it's own right by those who are exclusively interested in vehicle combat, it is also designed to fully integrate with the companion volume 'Kampfgruppe Eins' (Infantry Combat) for those who wish to explore joint operations between the two arms.

All that is required to play are models to represent the appropriate vehicles and terrain, a suitable playing area, six sided dice and a measuring device. Players are then at liberty to recreate combat involving motorcycles, Tiger tanks and everything in between.

The third in the Kampfgruppe system series, this volume covers weapon systems such as mortars, which provided infantry units with their own integral 'artillery' support (down to platoon level in most armies). It also considers rockets, which were frequently employed in the close support role during street fighting and 'bunker busting' operations along with various other weapons.

A ready reference section is provided to maintain the flow of play when major aspects of the various procedures need to be confirmed. A section is also presented dealing with defensive works along with scenario ideas and tactical information relating to attacks made against them.

By using the contents of this volume in conjunction with other 'Kampfgruppe' titles actions such as raids by commando or airborne units can be recreated from landing. Larger scenarios might involve amphibious landings in the Mediterranean or 'island hopping' in the Pacific. On a more routine level, the various sections of this volume can be employed to provide air and 'off table' artillery support during predominantly land actions. Similarly, come of the specialized combat engineering vehicles developed for the Normandy landings can be used to assist in overcoming difficulties further inland, as occurred in the actual conflict. In common with its companion titles, Kampfgurppe Vier is fully compatible with all other aspects of the'Kampfgruppe' system and can be employed fully, or in part, to suit the specific requirements of players.

From the publisher's Website

Baptism of Fire II, BoF II, is a complete revision and overhaul of the original ‘Baptism of Fire’ (BoF) and ‘Wild Fire’ (WF) miniature wargames. The result will seem familiar to players of these first games, but in many of the mechanisms and details there has been change.

The changes have made for standardized systems, which are both easy to teach and remember in play. The text is clearer with more and better examples. It has also been organized by a group of players like yourself, so hopefully finding information in a hurry will be easier.

BoF II continues as a leading miniature skirmish game, for games of Squads up to reinforced Platoon level from WW2 to present day. It includes rules for all manner of infantry and vehicle operations. There are additional optional rules to further enhance the gaming experience.

The rules are aimed to create as authentic a battlefield experience as possible, players are encouraged to utilize real life battlefield strategies and tactics as these will give great success.

BoF II continues using a similar system as Baptism of Fire and Wild Fire to create a highly interactive, unpredictable, yet the player can try and exert a degree of control and planning to implement his strategies and tactics.

Valor & Victory is a game of WWII Squad-Level Combat

Through the shattered ruins of a quaint European village, to the scorched sands of North Africa, and on the deadly beaches of a mist-shrouded Pacific island, Valor & Victory puts you in command of the troops and machines that fought across the battlefields of World War II.

Valor & Victory is a fast playing, easy to learn World War II squad-level game system. V&V gets you into the action quickly, without requiring you to learn a lot of minutiae and unnecessary detail. But don't let that fool you — Valor & Victory is a complete WWII wargaming system, covering infantry and armored combat, artillery and air strikes, snipers, close assaults, armored overruns, fortifications, and much more!

Valor & Victory may be easy to learn, but it's challenging and fun. So whether you're looking for an evening of serious wargaming action, or simply a quick battle at lunch, Valor & Victory delivers!

New players are advised to download a limited set of files to try 3 scenarios, before deciding to dive deeper into the game.
See below in the "Community Wiki" section.

item.description:
From the intro:

Wild Fire, or WF, is a table top miniature wargame for 10-30 mm figures. It is focussed on reinforced platoon level skirmish games, and is suitable for one off games, or campaigns, but can be used to play games as small as squad size. It uses the same system as Baptism of Fire.

It's been reprinted together with the WWII rules in Baptism of Fire II.

name.value: The New Yorker: Cartoon Caption Game

item.description:
Each player writes a caption to a cartoon from New Yorker magazine. Whomever is "it" this turn guesses who wrote each one. Players score for guessing right and for fooling others. Like Balderdash, only much funnier!

from the publisher:

Based on The New Yorker’s popular Cartoon Caption Contest comes a game of immeasurable creativity, unmatched wit, and uproarious humor…and you are responsible for, well, most of it.

If a picture speaks a thousand words, surely you can come up with a few of your own in this hilarious game of ‘which player wrote which caption’. And don’t worry about not being funny. In a game like this, even the ‘bad’ captions are part of the fun!

link.value: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

item.description:
From the intro:

"Rattenkrieg" is designed as a stand alone game system that allows players to recreate fighting in built up areas during the Second World War. However, because it is based on the popular, tried and tested 'Kampfgruppe' series it is also compatible with the rest of Dropwing's World War Two titles, allowing scenarios of infinite variety to be created.

Urban fighting is held by many to be one of the most challenging aspects of modern warfare and this is equally reflected by the challenge of representing such combat on the war games table. This volume enables various types of infantry and vehicles to test their mettle against some of the unique situations to be encountered whilst fighting in built up areas.

Some of the most significant battles of the Second World War were fought in urban surroundings, such as Berlin, the Warsaw Uprising and perhaps most notably Stalingrad. However, it should also be remembered that, in addition to such epic and historically significant encounters, countless smaller actions took place within the towns and villages along the paths of advance made at all stages of the war. The prime purpose of "Rattenkrieg" is to enable this style of combat, along with its unique atmosphere and challenges, to be recreated on the tabletop.

Special procedures are presented to incorporate sniper duels, sewer fighters and tank hunting teams, in addition to more mainstream combatants. Ready reference sheets are printed on facing pages and due to the comb binding the book can be opened flat to speed up play by having all of the main procedures available at a glance.

"Rattenkrieg" also includes a scenario based on an historical event, which can be used to introduce new players to the game as well as form a basis for experiment with various aspects of the game.

Road Cycling Tour (RCT) is a road cycling simulation focusing on team tactics in multi-stage races. By means of road/track tiles stages can be built to simulate real or imaginary cycling events. Movement is modified roll-and-move with some additional rules for breakaways and closing gaps (as a simulation of slipstreaming). The characteristics or qualities of the cyclists/riders are represented with 'speed counters' that can be used to replace or in addition to the dice. Teams should generally have a balanced mix of riders with different specializations represented by different sets of speed counters.

A 'beginners' game' and rules for time trials, team time trials, and some advanced and optional rules are included with the game, but given the flexible nature of the game, players can easily make further adaptations to simulate their favorite cycling event. To further explain the most complex rules, a series of picture tutorials can be found in the 'rules forum' here.

RCT is not a short game. It is recommended to play at least 5 stages in a single game, and with 2 experienced players, that would take between 2 and 3 hours. More players and more (and/or longer) stages make the game longer, smaller teams make it shorter but have a negative effect on possible team tactics. However, RCT is played stage by stage, and it would be easy to play different stages on different occasions.

The game is a free download. All necessary files are available in the files section here.

Made by Mattel in 1996 for 2-4 players Ages 10 and up.

A rapid fire memory challenge.

COMPLETE contents include: 1 VHS tape, 1 large playing deck, colored chips, plastic insert, and the instructions.

Test your memory and bluffing skills. Match cards from your hand to pictures, which flash on the screen, to win more cards. The player with the most cards, when the deck runs out, wins the game.

name.value: Micro Force: The Game American Civil War

item.description:
From Back of Cover
Take command of a division in the Civil War with this fast-playing and fun system for tactical combat simulation. It has everything: rules, tables, a scenario generator plus a collection of prepared scenarios featuring many of the most popular battles of "The War Between the States."
- Game Rules and Tables for 10mm Miniatures
- Weapons Data for Artillery & Small Arms
- Scenario Design Guide
- 11 Ready-to-Play Historical Scenarios

SCALES:
1 infantry stand = +/- 70 men
1 cannon = a section (2 guns)
1" = 25 yards or meters
Typical 2 player game: 4' x 4' board; 2-3 hours

[Though a stand represents around 70 men, casualties are recorded for each half-stand. Thus a 5-stand regiment has 10 steps]

Both players try to lead their ice hockey team to victory.

The game's idea separates this game from other tactics and sports games:

Bodycheck. An on ice player may be moved only if he crosses the direct line between two players and their movement.

The movement possibilities of the skater do not depend the player's strengths but only on his position on game board. This underlines the team play aspect and creates an unusual play feeling for the game.

Source: Spielbox magazine

A CCG featuring all the mythical and historical Chinese heroes. There's Cao Cao from the Three Kingdoms; Lin Chung from the Water Margin; the Monkey King from Journey to the West; Bruce Lee etc.

The Starter Set kicked off with "Three Kingdoms I".

Following the Starter Set is "Expansion Set 1 : Water Margin I".

Canal 13 (Channel 13) and Ludik Toys have together developed a fantastic game based completely on the popular MaravilloZoo program. 
The wonderful thing about this game is that, as in the TV show, you can learn a lot of interesting things about the animal kingdom.

CONCEPT OF THE GAME: Each participant must compete showing his knowledge about the Animal Kingdom. For it, they will have to:

 answer questions or
 fulfill the challenges proposed in the game:
 draw an animal
 make charades of an animal
 explain an animal
 mention animals that fulfill certain characteristics
 discover an animal playing the "hanged person"
 etc.
 




A game for the whole family

Match Mate is a couples game featuring over 1,000 provocative questions in the categories of “Memory”, “Personality”, “Sensuality” and “Odds and Ends.” This game allows couples to see how well they really know each other.

Players move their pawns carefully through the haunted house gameboard in search of four different color treasures. When a player lands on one of the 40 face-down tokens on the gameboard, they flip it over where they might discover a treasure, a helpful token or...horrors, even a monster!

Classic Universal Monsters 'The Mummy', 'Mr.Hyde', 'Creature from the Black Lagoon', 'Dracula', 'Phantom of the Opera', 'Frankenstein' and 'Wolfman' are all hidden on the gameboard ready to scare or take your treasure. Once a monster has been turned over, any player may move the monster from room to room to look for an opponent. Once four different color treasures have been collected, make a break for one of the mansion exits to win the game!

From the Press Release:

Based on Sony’s star-studded CGI film “Surf’s Up” due in theaters nationwide in June 2007, this game will give everyone a sneak peak. Players must try to get their four penguins over the wave to the other side of the beach, but big penguins can keep the smaller ones from getting too far and the wave is unpredictable.

From the Press Release:

Visitors of the Horseland Web site, one of the top Web sites for girls with more than 3 million on-line users, and fans of the “Horseland” Saturday-morning television series can share their enthusiasm for horses with this board game. Players select their horses and try to earn points in different categories and compete to be the first player to get a blue ribbon.

From the Press Release:

Gives players an opportunity to role play as Ben Tennyson, star of Cartoon Network’s “Ben 10.” Using a replica of Ben’s Omnitrix, players must find out what alien they’ve become and then use that power to battle and get closer winning.

item.description:
An interactive children's memory game. Taking turns each player tries to find a matching 'Crazy Creature' which matches the Hide and Seek card. If a player successfully finds a match they can move 'IT' one space closer to their opponents Gotcha circle. When 'IT' reaches either players Gotcha circle the other player is the winner.

This game simulates a game of hide and seek and allows the players to interact with each other using phrases like 'You're it' and 'Gotcha'.

---

Find the hidden creatures to win this easy to play memory game.
For 2 players aged 4 years upwards

A game for 2 players aged 4 onwards.
OBJECT:
To keep out of the CAUGHT YOU space by selecting the correct hiding Crazy Creature.

PREPARATION:
1. Place the playing strip on the table with the yellow CAUGHT YOU space in front of one player sitting one side of the table and the blue CAUGHT YOU space in front of the other, sitting opposite.
2. Attach MR. IT to his stand and place him on the start facing the yellow end of the playing strip.
3. The player at the yellow and of the playing strip takes the eight HIDING PLACE cards with the yellow sky and places them lace (CRAZY CREATURE SIDE) down spread out in a straight line in front of him. The player at the blue and does the same with the blue cards.
4. The Crazy Creature cards are shuffled and stacked face down on the table between the two rows of HIDING PLACE cards.
5. The top Crazy Creature card is turned over, showing the players which creature they are looking for, and the game i.e. ready to begin.

HOW TO PLAY
The player on the yellow side of the playing strip starts by reaching over and turning one of his opponent's HIDING PLACE cards over to find the Crazy Creature of the same colour as on the card in the centre. If the creature on the HIDING PLACE card does not match he turns the "HIDING PLACE" card back over and his turn ends. The player on the blue side now turns one of his opponent’: HIDING PLACE cards to find the same Crazy Creature.
When a player turns a HIDING PLACE card and finds the matching Crazy Creature, he yells YOU'RE IT and turns MR. IT to face his opponent and moves MR. lT one step towards his opponent's CAUGHT YOU space. The hiding place card is left face up. He then turns over a new Crazy Creature card in the centre and goes again, looking for the next Crazy Creature.
If all 8 Crazy Creature cards in the centre have been turned over before MR. IT gets to a CAUGHT YOU space, the Crazy Creature cards are re-shuffled and placed face down between the players. The players then turn all hiding place cards Crazy Creature side down and rearrange them. The last player to find the hiding Crazy Creature continues the play and turns over the top Crazy Creature card in the centre.

When a player moves MR. IT into his opponent's CAUGHT YOU space, he wins the game.

item.description: Vegas Nite Bingo is played with a 56 card deck. Each card has a bingo letter and three numbers. The object is to play cards in front of you that spell BINGO. All players are dealt five cards. One player begins as the caller and turns over the top card in the deck. She then choses one of the three numbers on that card and "calls" that number. For instance O-43. Any players who have cards that match that number can play them in front of them and draw a new card. The caller does have a hand and can choose the number to call based on their cards. Play proceeds until a FREE card is drawn. When this happens the caller plays it as her own and any other FREE card is discarded, the deck then moves to the player on the left and they become the caller.
Players attempt to score goals by rolling three dice and moving a ball peg on a peg board. There is a different die for passes, shots and kicks.

item.description: Using three dice players play a three hole course moving ball pegs on a peg board. There are different dice for woods, irons, and a putter.

Players roll dice to move their car pegs around the track peg board. There are different dice for aggressive and normal racing and a pit stop die. This game is a very simple Indy style track on which you move a peg from hole to hole:- 7 per lap. Each player sticks to their own lane and has their own die which gives one of +1,+2,+3,-1,PIT,MISS. If in the pit, you use a pit die to decide whether or not you come out or stay there awhile.

This new edition of the previous limited edition has some new features and some rule changes which alter the traditional game.
1. As well as eight (8) Collectible playing pieces, including Snow White and Pinnochio, there is also a gold statuette of Tinkerbell. In a significant new rule change, when a player rolls a double Tinkerbell advances on to the next property. If a player lands on this property and it is already owned, then the Bank pays the fine. If the property is not owned then the player purchases it for free!
2. Magic Moments and Show Time cards replace Chance and Community Chest and are pleasantly well-themed.
3. Gameboard spaces contain the Disney films as the properties you are buying. In the center of the board is a magnificent pop-up Disney-style castle.
4. Stations have been replaced by modes of transport (including Mr Incredible’s car). The ‘stations’ are linked by a ‘pixie dust trail’. If a player ends their turn on a station they can choose to move to the next station (using up one point of their dice roll) and so on to move around the board quicker (and to avoid paying rent!).
5. The traditional houses and hotels have been replaced with Fairytale Cottages and Sleeping Beauty castles.
6. It is now possible for a player to be sent to the Castle Verandah instead of to jail.

item.description:
Admiral is an abstract, hex-based strategy game with a rock-paper-scissors mechanism.

The theme hinges around a French/British conflict about the South African colonies shortly before World War I. In reality the conflict was averted by the French need of British support against German aggression, but in Admiral it blooms out with a major naval engagement around southern Africa.

Each player controls three ship fleets, consisting of submarines, destroyers and cruisers. Each fleet has a command ship and a command base. If the command ship is sunk or the base is invaded the entire fleet is destroyed and its ships removed. Each player also controls a battleship which commands the entire fleet, and a corresponding fleet base. Sinking the opponents battleship or invading his fleet base wins the game.

On his turn a player may move one ship from each fleet or forgo moving one fleet in order to move the battleship instead. Ships move along the corners of the hexes, submarines in the hexes. Subs can sink cruisers and battleships, destroyers can sink subs, cruisers can sink destroyers and battleships can sink both cruisers and destroyers.

Admiral plays out similar to chess, a chess with four kings, an action point allowance system and a rock-paper-scissors capture mechanism.

The publisher claims Admiral to be playable by 2-6 players but in reality it is a pure two player game.

The Bible teams up with America’s favorite pass time.

Made by Rhythm Band in 1984 for 2 or more players.

Contents include: game board, 4 pawns, 4 card decks (single, double, triple, and home run), and the instructions.

A magnetic travel game.

Made by Pressman in 1990 for 2 players Ages 7 and up.

OBJECT: Capture your opponents’ pieces or occupy one of his red circles to win.

Contents include: game board, 14 magnetic pieces, and the instructions.

Made by Skelton Shelton Nelson in 1979.

Exclusive features of the game include: 7 variations enabling the player to participate at different skill levels, ranging from a simple puzzle, to an entire group participating in an old fashioned history bee; A laminated game board displaying a map of the USA which can be written on and erased; self-check answers; and an opportunity to program your own cards.

Contents include: game board, 2 dice, 50 state puzzle pieces, 4 tokens, instruction booklet, 14 packages of programmed information cards, 1 set of penalty cards, 1 wild card, 1 dead card, 1 7-section card holder, 1 board design strip, claiming circles, East and West land banks, and 4 Liberty Bell tokens.

Based on Tani Kosyu's novel and novellette series,"Koukuu-utyuugun-si (history of space army ?)", this game covers the most important episode in the novel.
Outer planets has made a revolt against the Earth. But, it could not be successful according to the novel.
This game simulates this revolt with "War at Sea" system.

1 map (separated into 4 pieces)
2 countersheets
1 rulebook (12 pages)

The website (Japanese) is
http://solger.sblo.jp/article/1087769.html

From the manufactuerer's web site:

Based on the Academy Award winning Dr. Seuss cartoon, and now featured everyday on the Cartoon Network, Gerald McBoing Boing Game is the story of 6-year-old Gerald: an adventurous little boy with a unique talent for speaking only in sound effects. The game allows young children to join Gerald on his adventures both big and small as he honks, whistles, clangs, toots, and cuckoos through his day. The fun game will entertain and teach, using sound association, to engage its younger players.

For 2 or more players Ages 3 - 6.

From the manufacturer's web site:

Shake, roll and race! This oversized mat game will have your kids begging to practice their math. Roll the soft foam numbers and operation dice and race to find the answer on the oversized number mat! This durable vinyl mat features all the answers (sums and differences) to addition and subtraction problems that use numbers 1 through 6. Includes 3 dice and 28 cardboard game markers.

Ages 5 - 8

For 2 or more players, Ages 7 and up.

This game won the 2004 National Young Game Inventors Contest. Players add, subtract, multiply, and divide to fill up their food cards. At the same time, they must use strategy to slow down their opponents. There are 3 ways to play.

name.value: Brown Bear - Panda Bear, What Do You See?

item.description:
A memory game loosely based on Eric Carle's Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See? and Panda Bear, Panda Bear, What Do You See? series of children's books.

2-4 players are either brown or panda bears; the pandas are looking for a set of endangered animals, while the browns are looking for a set of more mundane wildlife (albeit a bit weird, such as the blue horse). Each turn a player flips one tile from a center pool. If it fills an opening in their predefined set, they keep it and take one (and only one) more turn. If not, they turn it back over. First player to fill their whole set wins.

The two turn limit makes this more suited to very young children than traditional memory games, as there's never too many recently-flipped tiles to track. Most of the time there's either zero or one, since rejected animals are usually quickly picked up by the next player in line.

Claims that the game helps with sequencing skills are based on the endgame, when the winning player calls out each of their animals in order, aping the book series' style. (The animals can be picked up in any order.)

Each player thinks of a subject and secretly writes words relating to it on a planner, like a little crossword.

The other players call off positions on the board, finding the letters that make up the words.

By challenging and naming a word before it is complete, players can earn bonus points, but lose points if they are wrong.

Puzzlewords will increase your word power and provoke laughter and discussion all around the table.

From the manufacturer's web site:

Players reach under the bed to find the matches on their score card. The monster gets nervous if a player is looking too long and will growl a warning sign. If a player has their hand under the bed for too long the monster pops out of the head board and that player has to clear off their score card. The first player to find and match three items in a row, wins! Includes 9Wx8Hx12L electronic monster bed, 12 gross objects, 4 score cards, 40 chips, and instructions. No reading required.

Ages 4 and up

item.description:
Spear Song is a set of tabletop wargame rules primarily based on the Dark Age/Medieval period. By concentrating on the 'mechanics' of pre-gunpowder warfare, rather than focusing on particular armies or battles, the system should be flexible enough to cater for the historical preferences of most players who are interested in this era. Rules for chariots and 'Eastern style' warriors further increase the potential by allowing for Celtic or Crusader type settings.

Whilst the rules are mainly designed to create skirmishes and small-scale actions, a section is also included to enable larger scale battles to be fought using the same basic system.

Each major section of the text is followed by a fictional narrative that explains how the system works in game terms, and an introductory scenario based around the narratives is provided to familiarize players with the game.

As with other Dropwing systems, it is intended to extend the historical material that we produce in line with market demand. Having said this, Spear Song provides a 'stand alone' system in it's own right, which provides players with the basic material to fight battles using a wide variety of warriors from the 'Sword and Shield' era.

name.value: Tamagotchi Electronic Grow Your Pet Game

item.description:
From the Press Release:

Based on Bandai’s popular line of Tamagotchi virtual pets, this board game allows fans to start out as an egg and try to be the first player to evolve to adulthood. An electronic “Tamascreen” selects players’ meals, toys, snacks and more, and Tamagotchi-themed challenges help players win.

Meta is a gaming system, consisting of a 10x10 board that may be laid down or stood upright and 44 wooden tokens in 3 colors. The 8 dark green tokens are identical on both sides, but the yellow and light green ones have a dot on one of their sides. The components are of excellent quality.

The system comes with four games:
Menos: an evolution of solitaire where the player jumps over the pieces to remove them (for one player).
Esca: a five-in-a-row game, where the board stands upright with the two players on either side. Players try to make 2 5-in-a-rows by placing their tokens, blocking and removing enemy tokens.
Tremplin: a chinese checkers sort of game where players try to reach their respective goals by jumping over pieces. (2 configurations: for 2 or 4 players)
Arriba: an original concept where the board is positioned at an angle. Players try to reach the top row but the holes become deeper and deeper towards it, so multiple tokens have to be positioned in the holes to create stepping stones.

A trivia game about Finnish rock music from the 70's to 00's. The game includes a four-piece game board, 180 question cards and a dvd together with about 1000 questions. The dvd contains video and music samples. There are two different playing options: you can either play a quick game or a regular game. The publisher is a Finnish record company.

item.description:
From the publisher's website

Terminus V is an elaborate combination of actual and purely imaginary elements. It’s particularly hard to define where the “real” ends and the “fictional” begins. For those of you who follow military and scientific matters, you’re likely to spot where reality meets fiction-although in some cases, you may not be able to clearly distinguish between these boundaries. However, it really isn't important where the lines blur a bit. The fuzzy area where reality and fiction intermix is intentional. The real fun is in the game itself and what you can (or can’t) make of it to be successful in your mission and/or goals!

You can play T5 strictly as a miniatures game, a roleplaying game, or both simultaneously. As you will see, the Character Profile Log sheets can be filled out and set up to use either way, depending upon the amount of information you want to know, or need to have, about a character. The game can easily be converted into a dual miniatures/roleplaying game simply by choosing to play one character as yourself while the rest of your team (Strike Cell) is played normally as miniatures would be.

T5 is excellent for present-day combat simulation gaming too! The unique and versatile Com20 game system mechanics give you everything you need to game battles taking place today--with no modifications necessary! See the T5 Action! page for additional details.

Designed for the University of Notre Dame. Made by Late For The Sky Production Company.

COMPLETE contents include: 1 game board, 5 tokens, 2 dice, years of credit cards, diplomas, campus mail and contingency cards, property deeds, play money , instructions and original plastic insert.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
The Ice Cream Cone Game.

Made by Western Publishing in 1977 for 2-4 players Ages 7 - 12.

OBJECT: Be the first players to get an ice cream cone from the ice cream shop to Donald and Daisy.

COMPLETE contents include: 12 playing pieces, spinner, game board, and the instructions printed on the inside of the box top.

A happy game for 2-4 players Ages 4 and up. No reading required!

Made by Colorforms in 1981.

OBJECT: Travel along the starry trail, jump over the moon, and be the first player to arrive home.

COMPLETE contents include: platform game board, spinner, 4 colorful cows, 4 wooden sticks, and the instructions printed on the box top.

Simple Trick taking game with a nice twist: You don't have the cards on the hands but they are on the table on 4 face-up piles. So you have to play the upper cards to get to the lower ones.
Also you can play several cards at once, adding their value up but with the risk of running out of cards before the end of the round

This is basically Risk using the United States, instead of the world, as a map. There are 51 territories (the states and the District of Columbia) in which to place the four colors of plastic chips (each representing "an army of 1,000 soldiers). Set-up, by alternate picking of territories, and die roll combat is identical to Risk. The came contains 153 cards (infantry, cavalry, and "governor" cards for each of the 51 territories), and card play is significantly different from Risk, as a card from a stack of shuffled infantry and cavalry cards is picked every time a territory is conquered. If a player acquires both the infantry and cavalry cards for a state, the player is awarded the governor card for that state and immediately takes that state over. If another player has the other card, there is a one-die showdown to determine control. Play continues until all 102 infantry/cavalry cards are drawn, and the winner is the player with the most territories at that time. The game is well-made, with front & back box printing, a mounted board, plastic insert, 153 cards, 6 dice, 4 sets of 64 plastic chips, and three rules booklets (English, Spanish, French).

Get ready for fun questions, ridiculous answers and nonstop laughter as you and your friends take turns guessing which player wrote which answer while writing your own personal answers to suggestive, silly, and stimulating questions. The ADULT version of the best-selling Loaded Questions is more than suggestive, more than funny, and (from both laughter and embarrassment) just might make your cheeks as red as the cover of the box!

item.description:
From the publisher:

TV trivia at its best!
With 50 years of TV packed into two DVDs, the Deluxe TV Edition of Scene It? is the quintessential television trivia game. From The Brady Bunch to Alias this game will keep players tuned in for hours and hours of TV entertainment.

From the publisher:

Double your Friends fun with 2 DVDs!
From Marcel the Monkey and Smelly Cat to foosball and Ugly Naked Guy, you'll relive all your favorite moments from all your favorite episodes, through real show clips, trivia questions and an array of on-screen puzzlers compiled from all ten seasons of the hit show Friends.

Deluxe Edition Game Includes:

 Collectible Tin 
 2 DVDs (includes bonus DVD) 
 Flextime® Game Board 
 Party Play 
 6 Collectible Metal Tokens (2 extra Tokens) 
 200 Trivia Cards (25% more Trivia Cards) 
 30 Buzz Cards 
 4 Reference Cards 
 1 Six-Sided Die 
 1 Eight-Sided Die

From the publisher:

Now available in a distinctive game tin, Scene It? Deluxe Disney Edition offers more clips and characters from your favorite Disney and Pixar movies, more trivia questions and more on-screen challenges than ever before. A true family game, Scene It? Deluxe Disney Edition comes with separate trivia cards for adults and kids and a second game disc, featuring a unique Party Play setting, voiced by Christy Carlson Romano (Kim Possible, Even Stevens), who reads the questions and answers aloud for younger players to enjoy on their own.

Deluxe Edition Game Includes:

 Collectible Tin 
 2 DVDs (includes bonus DVD) 
 Flextime® Game Board 
 Party Play 
 6 Collectible Metal Tokens (2 extra Tokens) 
 200 Trivia Cards (25% more Trivia Cards) 
 30 Buzz Cards 
 4 Reference Cards 
 1 Six-Sided Die 
 1 Eight-Sided Die 
 Set of Game Rules

This game for Ages 4 and up and up helps them learn beginning math concepts like counting on. It plays similar to war, but instead of a standard playing card deck, each card shows a small sum represented by dots of different colors. Children lay down cards, then determine if they've won the hand by adding the sums. Comes with 24 large cards.

Mr Game is a self contained game module system that contains the parts, boards and instructions to play 20 games: Baseball Bagatelle, Beat The Banker, Buck Dice, Checkers, Eight By Eight, Fox and Geese, Happy Face Puzzle, Help Your Neighbor, Hoop-La, Hoses and Ladders, Morris The Farmer, Parchisi, Queen Bee, Ship Captain Mate and Crew, Shuffleboard, Solitaire, Spin A Winner, Steeplechase, Tic-Tac-Toe, and Tiddly Winks. The central Mr Game figure is used in many of these games, making standard games unique to Mr Game (for example, one of his arms shoots the shuffleboard disks and the balls for Baseball Bagatelle). Designed and play tested with target audience of Ages 5 and up

From the Introduction to the Rules:
"Eye Jinxx, the jigsaw puzzle board game, can be enjoyed several ways.
It can be assembled cooperatively, by one or more persons, without rules or time constraints.
It can be assembled competitively, by two or more players/teams, in accordance with the rules, time limits, and scoring format provided. We recommend a maximum of FOUR teams, with no more than SIX players per team.
Also, whether playing cooperatively or competitively, there is the ongoing challenge of locating the eight hidden objects.
We recommend that prior to playing the game, the puzzle be assembled and the hidden objects be located."
Components include jigsaw puzzle pieces, game board, D6 die, 4 pencils, 3 minute sand timer, score pad, and 4 hidden object cards.
NGC 404
Copyright 1990 by Strathcona Mosaic Limited.
Played on a high gloss durable mat that measures 2 feet by 4 feet, players flick a ringed ball-bearing towards the hole in a game that simulates the game of golf.

The game of baseball now in finger form. One player pitches and the other bats. The pitch starts by flicking the marker towards home plate. Based upon where it lands the result could be a ball, strike, pending hit, or a player choices. If it's a pending hit, then the batter must flick the marker and land on the corresponding "hit" location, otherwise it's an out.

item.description:
This is a word meaning game with some particularities:
1.- It has card with STRANGE words, so they are very difficult and, because not a lot people know their meaning, allows to bluff and laugh a lot.
2.- Players start in the ignorance gear and must go until the knowledge gear.
3.- Each player has it’s own path on the board.
4.- Each path is different because contains different icons, that allows you to get bonus points if the image on the gear you are on mach the one in the card being played.

As with all this kind of games, players must give the meaning of the word that appears in a card. In they don’t know it they must bluff, so he can convince the other players that his meaning is the right one. Each time they get a vote, he advance in the board until one of them reaches the knowledge gear.

item.description:
A published Bridge variant.
It uses Jill cards to allow the declarer to call "his" or "hers".
HIS ranks: A K Q Jack Jill 10 9 8 7 6 5 4 3 2
HER ranks: A Q K Jill Jack 10 9 8 7 6 5 4 3 2
A few other rules change this game from the standard Bridge game.

Thrilling Tales of Adventure! is set in the world of pulp fiction and adventure serials of the 1920s and 1930s. One player, the Arch Villain, attempts to build and execute dastardly plots while the remaining players -- each of whom assumes the role of a classic pulp hero -- try to foil these plots. Among the 10 heroes to choose from are Samantha Starr (intrepid girl reporter) the Amazing Uri (former magician to the Tsar), and the Blue Falcon (ace aviatrix). The game plays out over three Acts, as the Arch Villain works toward the execution of a final Master Plan, such as the construction and activation of a massive death ray, or encasing the world in ice for all eternity.

The key mechanic of the game is the creation of "Adventures," linked sets of cards that the Heroes must investigate and overcome in order to collect Heroism points. There are two types of Adventures: "Wild Adventures," which are generated on the fly by a combination of card plays and draws from the various decks; and "Plots," which are custom-built by the Arch Villain player and have much higher stakes.

This game is basically a copy of the Hasbro-Game "Taboo": You explain words to your team members and try to avoid certain "Stopp-Words". Main difference: The explanation time is much shorter and you are only allowed to explain 1 card.

The game is played with 5 dice that are marked like playing cards. They have values: 9, 10, J, Q, K, A. One player puts the dice in the box and shakes to randomize. The player then looks at the dice without revealing their value to the other players. The player who "rolled" states a value for the dice which may be true or false. The other players must decide if they want to believe or doubt the value of the dice.

Finger Ball**
 


Two players. Each player reveals 1,2 or 3 fingers from his or her hand, rock-paper-scissors style.

If a player reveals exactly two more fingers than his opponent, then he scores a touchdown (7 pts)

If a player reveals exactly one less finger than his opponent, then he scores a field goal (3 pts)

If both players reveal the same number, the quarter ends.

Most points after four completed quarters wins.

Examples:
Herman reveals 1 finger
Jorge reveals 3 fingers
JORGE SCORES A TOUCHDOWN (7 pts)

Herman reveals 1 finger
Jorge reveals 2 fingers
HERMAN SCORES A FIELD GOAL (3 pts)

item.description:
Part Bingo, part Memory. Be the first to complete your Bingo card by collecting matching pairs and you win. Contents: 16 wooden matching pairs, 4 wooden Bingo cards, and a cotton pouch.

For Ages 4 and up.

From the box:

CALLING ALL TABLETOP SPORTS FANS!

Flex your fingers and get ready to flick! Inside this cool package you'll find everything you need to play tabletop soccer, hockey, AND football!


 26 punch-out pieces for players, ballsa, and pucks!
 Two sturdy goalposts!
 Stickers!
 Dozens of game rules, flick tips, and more!

 Amazing finger flick techniques!
 Team uniform tips!
 Tabletop game rules!
 Scoring strategies!

One of Australia's many contributions to the world of gambling. The game is conducted in a flat circle of approximately 20 feet (6 metres) or larger. The only equipment required (aside from materials for tracking bets) is two coins (by tradition pre-decimal pennies), and a flat piece of wood called the "kip" approximately 8 inches in length which has holes carved in it to fit the coins neatly but loosely enough for the coins to come out when tossed.

The game is run by a "boxer", who calls the first "potato" (one of the players around the circle) in to toss the coins. The spinner wagers an amount of their choice on either "heads" or "tails". Other players around the ring can then also bet on either "heads" or "tails". .

Once all bets are taken, the boxer calls "no more bets", and the player tosses the coins in the air using the kip. To be a valid throw, they must go above the head height of the spinner, be rotating sufficiently and land entirely in the ring - if they do not the boxer calls "barred" and the throw is retaken. Ideally the call must occur before the coins settle.

If the coins land both on the same face, the round ends and non-spinning player's bets are paid off, with people who bet on the same face as that landed winning. A new round of non-spinner bets is then taken before the spinner throws again.

If the coins come up with one tail and one head, the spinner spins again. If 5 "odds" come up, all players lose and a new spinner is selected.

If the spinner throws his nominated face three times before either 5 "odds" being thrown in a row, or a spin with both coins being the opposite face, the spinner wins and is paid at 7.5 to 1 (in most modern games).

Odd is a simple abstract game for 2 players, with stones of 2 colors, typically played on a hexagonally tiled board with 5 cells on each edge (though it can be played on almost any tiling). Odd can also be played with pencil and paper.

Definitions: 

 A group is a set of stones on the board, all of the same color, for which it is possible to trace a continuous path between any two of them by stepping between adjacent stones of that color.
 The size of a group is the number of stones in it. 




Rules:

 The board begins empty.
 Players take turns. On each turn a player places one stone of either color onto any empty space.
 The game ends when the board is full. Player 1 wins if there is an odd number of groups of at least size 5 on the board, and Player 2 wins otherwise. When counting groups, be sure add up the total number of connected groups of both colors.




Notes:

 One can change the character of the game by increasing or decreasing the minimum size which a group must have in order to be counted at the end. The larger the minimum group size, the more strategic and less tactical the game becomes, and vice-versa

item.description:
The updated version of 1984's Oz Quiz.
The crazy, zany around-Australia trivia game.
Over 2000 questions. Comes packaged in an esky as per the original.

This is children’s game that contains rules and card sets for Math Rummy and Alphabet Go Fish. Also included in the box are four children’s card holders to allow young children hold a hand of cards.

The Math Rummy game has 24 cards that contain number cards (1-10) and plus cards, minus cards and a board to create simple equations. The Math Rummy rules contain the rules for two games of various difficulties as well as teach-me tips on using this game with children.

The Alphabet Go Fish game has 78 cards, three of each letter with a representative item for that letter on the card (ex. key for k). The cards are also in six different colors to allow for color matching games. The Alphabet Go Fish rules contain the rules for three games of various difficulty as well as teach-me tips on using this game with children.

Omniana is a fantasy card game in which players use their imagination to creatively debate battles between many strange & absurd characters in a multitude of exotic & normal locations.
 On each Character Card there is a brief description of an original character detailing his special abilities, weaknesses and history. Players take turns sending one of their characters into an opponent's situation to battle against that opponent's pre-selected character. One or more of the remaining players will judge each battle. Using only the information on their cards, both of the battling players must argue how and why his character would win in a duel. The judge(s) decides the victor and awards him either a treasure or an advantage card. The player with the most treasure at the end of the game wins.

Home Page: http://www.omnianathegame.com

"Clapping, Barking, Bobbing, and Tipping - the motorized hoopla game!"

Toss rings around the neck of a motorized seal as it bobs around and makes seal noises.

From the manufacturer's web site:

Join Pooh, Piglet, Eeyore and Tigger for a most exciting adventure. Collect everything on your list. Everyone wins!
Several ways to play for different skill levels. Features chunky cards for small hands.

Develops shape and color recognition, counting skills and cooperative play.

For Ages 3 and up.

name.value: Do You Sudoku? Game for Kids

item.description:
To play, players roll the die, make the sound of the animal on the die, then try to place that animal on their grid. This is a kids version of Do You Sudoku? that involves 6 animals pictures on a 6 X 6 grid instead of the numbers 1 - 9 on a 9 X 9 grid.

From the publisher's web site:
Find a Home for Every Animal on the Farm!

Oink! Moo! Baa! Our Do you Sudoku? Game for Kids brings the logic solving challenge of Sudoku puzzles together with cute farm animals. Here's a fun way for children and parents to play together while developing patterning and logic skills.

Players roll a die, make the noise of their favorite animals and try to place the animal tile onto the correct space.

The Rules Are Simple
No animal can appear twice in the same 6 square box or in a line up and down or in a line across.

Contains 30 puzzle cards (60 puzzles), 108 animal tiles and 1 die.

Ages 6 & up.
Large, colorful football themed boardgame with beautiful graphics. Comes with wooden play pieces and spinners.

The Colts Super Bowl XLI Champions Edition of the Monopoly game is the only game that allows Colts fans the opportunity to buy, sell and trade the greatest players and coaches from the Super Bowl XLI Champion Colts in an effort to control their favorite team. Bankrupt your opponents and own it all. A must have for all Colts fans!

Officially licensed by the NFL

item.description:
ShaNuCo, according to the game's rulebook, stands for Shapes, Numbers and Colors.

It is a card game with 76 very large playing cards (Approx. 3" x 4"). Of these, 64 are marked with all combinations of the numbers 1-4, each color of blue, red, purple and green, and either a circle, star, square or triangle.

The rest of the cards are either Wild, Super Wild, Pass or Show cards, in some combination of the three characteristics that the main cards represent.

It's box is approximately 4.5" x 6" x 1". Instructions are in English, French and Spanish, and fit on both sides of a 4" x 6" sheet of paper (per language).

2-4 Players. 
The box claims 4-104 as appropriate ages for the game, but the rules are possibly too sophisticated for a child under 6 or 8 years of age.

The object of the game is to gain the most points after 5 rounds of play. Each player starts with 100 points, and each round a player may both gain or lose points, depending on game play.

Copyright 1996.
Published by International Playthings, Inc. (Parsippany, NJ, USA), it appears to be their product number P55001. Also credited on the box are Creative Concepts, Inc. and Excel Development Group, Inc. "Made in Canada"

Dexterity game that features mitts shaped to look like Fred, Wilma, Barney and Betty. The object of the game is to keep a ball balanced on the mitt without it rolling off as you try to do a series of moves determined by cards that you draw.

The game is played on a 16-square foot playing mat with an electronic helicopter placed in the middle and controlled from a remote that runs under the mat. Players choose to be either Blue or Red (teams can be created if there are more than 2 players)and alternate turns. The object of the game is to collect bomb tokens totaling 6 or more points before the other player(or team).

The tokens are spread out on the mat with the point value face down and the player must pick up the tokens with the helicopter(the points become visible once picked up)and dropped onto the designated headquarters. There are also bomb and spy tokens that need to be dropped into the bomb bunker or the competing players headquarters, respectively.

That is the main play, there are also solo mission and time variations.

Alphabet Soup Word Game. Object is to construct words and achieve the highest letter word score in a given period of time. The Goomicus is a free letter and can be used to represent any letter of the alphabet. Ages 6 and up

Contents: Instruction pamphlet; bowl; spoon; 130 letters (8 of which are Goomicus (wild))

A computer with electronic lights and sounds. You have to do what Einstein tells you to do. Similar to "Simon" and "Maniac".

Made by Castle Toy Company in 1979 for ages 6 to adult and one or more players. Requires four “C” batteries.

name.value: Walt Disney's Mickey Mouse If I Were In Your Shoes Game

item.description: Collect the most tokens by staying out of another player's shoes. Ages 8 and up

From the manufacturer's site:

I have Alex the Lion! Who has Marty the Zebra? If you have the right cards and the right speed - you win! Kids will love playing with their favorite Madagascar characters as they race to respond in order to win the game. This game also helps children build letter recognition and strengthen their reading vocabulary by using picture clues. Housed in a sturdy travel-tin, this card game includes two decks for two different ways to play. Includes 24 animal cards with green borders and 24 animal/letter cards with blue borders.

Ages 4 and up.

Made by Ponder Mason Games in 1986 for Ages 7 and up.

Bones is a high rolling, exciting and challenging dice game with a race to get bonus points. It may be played solitaire or as many players as one wishes.

COMPLETE contents include: 5 dice, score cards, roll em’ bones pencil, and the instructions.

OBJECT: Finish the game with the highest score. Fun and thrills till the very last roll.

The game of fun and laughs for girls. So much fun your friends won’t want to leave!

Made by Cadaco in 1990 for up to six girls Ages 8 and up.

OBJECT: Be the first player to get rid of all your rollers, by acting, drawing, answering questions, doing a silly stunt, whatever the game cards tell you to do.

Contents include: 30 plastic hair rollers, pencil, timer, 110 game cards, Dear Diary with notepad, and the instructions.

A geography game made by Whitman in 1962 for 2-4 players Ages 12 and up.

A help yourself educational game for home and school.

COMPLETE contents include: large world map, colored disks, question cards, smaller map, cardboard inserts, and the instructions.

OBJECT: To acquire the greatest number of points by identifying locations indicated on the cards.

"In Other Words...
is a fun-filled mix of recall, deduction, strategy and wit. Players advance around the board by solving paraphrased clues to well-known titles, common terms, and popular sayings."

This game bills itself as the "Original Game of Paraphrases".

In this game, players move around the board and solve puzzles in one of five categories
-Movies and Television
-Terms
-Quotes & Sayings
-Literature
-Cliches & Expressions
-Music

The puzzles are in the form of phrases that have to be translated into the actual saying on the card. For example, the movie "Away With the Breeze" is "Gone With the Wind", and the book "The Victor's Ring" is "The Winner's Circle".

This game has 2 levels of play for children Ages 3 and up. For the littlest children, you move according to color on the die. Older children move by number. It's a race to make it through the jungle, but meanwhile a lion is sleeping to his favorite song. If he wakes up during a child's move, they must hide in a bush. The first to get through the jungle wins.

A storytelling game for 2 to 4 players ages Ages 3 - 8.

The game consists of a board, spinner, and grab bag full of little toys. On each turn, a player gets to pick a toy from the bag. When a player lands on a storytelling space, he must tell a story involving all of the toys he has collected and the picture on the space he landed on. The first player to tell two stories wins.

name.value: One Fish Two Fish Red Fish Blue Fish Game

item.description:
For 2 to 4 players Ages 3 - 8.

Use your magnetic fishing pole to collect fish and put them together to make a puzzle. Includes 4 fishing poles, and 16 fish in 4 different colors.

Fictionary is as rich as the idea is basic, and each game is completely different.

It is played with a dictionary. Each player takes two sheets of paper. One will be used for definitions, and each player writes his name on top of it. The other will be used for guesses. One of the players takes the dictionary and looks for an obscure word that, he thinks, all other players ignore (i.e. eguzla, exarch or jabot). He spells the word and tells what kind of word (verb, name, adjective).

Each player must now imagine and write down a plausible and convincing definition for this word. The player with the dictionary writes the true definition. When all players have written their definition down, the player with the dictionary takes all sheets, shuffles them, numbers, and reads aloud all the definitions. If necessary, he may read those two or three times. Each player must then write on his guess sheet who, in his opinion, has written each definition.

When all players have written their definitions, the player with the dictionary unveils the truth and tells who wrote what. Each player scores:

 2 points if he found out the dictionary
 1 point for each other player he found out
 1 point for each player who thought his definition was the dictionary's one
 If no one guessed what the true definition was, the player with the dictionary scores as many points as there are players.




When all players have scored their points, the player with the dictionary gives it to the player on his left. Play goes on until each player has had the dictionary once or twice.

There are numerous variants at http://www.faidutti.com/index.php?Module=ludotheque&id=58.

Fictionary is also described at Wikipedia.

Balderdash is a popular commercial version of this game

Read the clue on the card, spin the wheel and the first person who calls out a correct answer starting with the letter spun keeps the card which is counted as one point.

Similar to another game I know but this has a very solid well made wooden spinner with all the letters of the alphabet on it.

From Publisher:
The fantastical world of Valon in the Dark Age. The time of swords and decaying Empires when Wylde Magicke ruled. Monsters and mayhem fit for champions. A world consumed by war and plunder where you as a Hero lead your band on a quest for riches and fame. Will the fates shine on you?

DarkeStorme has an easily learned 2D6 based rules system that is scenario driven with a normal game lasting between one and two hours in play. The game book features full rules, no need for expansions, create and advance your characters and creatures using a full points and species generation system. Also a full magic system and all needed rules for Chariots, Artillery and Monsters. Generate scenarios, the terrain and even the weather!
